talk.start.para: —Over the last five years, in the face of the deteriorating situation in our public hospitals, the private hospitals have sought to meet their patients' needs by establishing emergency services. Together, they have in fact provided an equivalent amount of accident and emergency services for private patients as would have been provided by the addition of one major teaching hospital. The private hospitals are not the cause of this problem; they are doing something to make up for the shortfall in public hospital services in South Australia.

speech.para: South Australia has a particular problem with its public hospital system. That was caused by Mr Brown when he was Premier. According to the Commonwealth Grants Commission 1999 report on general revenue grant relativities, Mr Brown cut South Australia's own sourced public hospital funding in constant 1997-98 prices from $394 million in 1993-94—Labor's last state budget—to $270 million in 1996-97, the last budget before Mr Brown was deposed as Premier. That is a reduction of $124 million in public hospital funding per year—these are Grants Commission figures. I note that Mr Brown was reported in the Australian on 19 February this year as criticising the Howard government's $2 billion private health insurance rebate because it failed to take the pressure off public hospitals. The reason South Australia's public hospitals are under so much pressure is that Mr Brown has personally been responsible for closing 553 public hospital beds. The federal Minister for Health and Aged Care, Dr Wooldridge, responded to Mr Brown's comments by pointing out that South Australia consistently failed to invest all its tied Commonwealth funds into hospitals. The situation would be that much worse if the private hospitals had not set up accident and emergency services.

In the few moments I have left, I would like to make a couple of observations about the progress of the foreign investment application by Shell for its takeover bid for Woodside Petroleum. I first spoke on this matter in the House on 6 February this year. On that occasion, I set out what is the national interest in the case of this application, and that is that exploration and development of the North West Shelf not be impeded by the conflicting interests of Shell. Those conflicts were confirmed by none other than the Shell executive in charge of its bid for Woodside, Raoul Restucci, who was quoted by the business editor of the Scottish paper, the Evening News, as saying:

quote.para: If Shell wins control after the shareholder vote, probably in late March or April, it will aim to stop Woodside from competing directly with Shell, as it has in liquefied natural gas receiving terminals in China and India.

speech.para: Shell has done nothing but dissemble in relation to that statement which reveals Shell's intention to ensure the operations of the North West Shelf joint venture do not conflict with Shell's other interests when the opposite should be the case. It is evidence that there is a very significant national interest issue remaining in relation to this application. I understand from Shell that they were looking at what unilateral undertakings they could make that would address the conflict of interest problem they so obviously have. However, unilateral undertakings would be inadequate because to be effective any changes to the government's arrangements of the North West Shelf joint venture that could protect our national interest would require the agreement of the North West Shelf joint venture partners. In turn, those changes would require the agreement of at least some of the non-Shell joint venture partners' bankers. Arrangements of that nature would be likely to take quite some time to negotiate. I understand that the government has put some conditions to Shell and the other joint venture partners apart from Woodside. I do not know whether those conditions are likely to be acceptable either to Shell or to the other North West Shelf partners, nor am I convinced that the conditions are likely to protect the national interest, but I would counsel the government that it not be dictated to by Shell's timetable in working through those issues to ensure that the national interest is protected.

Finally, I note reports in relation to the BHP-Billiton dual listing that the BHP Petroleum chief executive will move to London. There is no guarantee that other elements of the BHP Petroleum management will not soon follow. I have little doubt that, if Shell's takeover of Woodside is successful, that company will soon resemble a branch office. In my own state, the position of Australia's largest onshore operator Santos is presently protected by an act of the South Australia parliament which limits shareholdings in it to 15 per cent. That legislation is presently under review and, if it is changed, with a lower dollar, Santos could become a takeover target. Within a short period, we could lose the head offices of all our major Australian petroleum companies. I question whether that would be in the national interest.

talk.start.para: —I raise today the concerns of hundreds and possibly thousands of constituents from Park Orchards in my electorate who learned recently of a proposal by Vodafone to erect a 40-metre telecommunications tower in the midst of their neighbourhood. Park Orchards, I should indicate to the House, has long been regarded as a model of environmental balance in a residential area. Partly designed by Walter Burley Griffin and nestled amongst the native gums along Mullum Mullum Creek, it is known as part of the `green wedge' in Melbourne's eastern suburbs. For decades, residents jealously guarded their environment, resisting incursions from those who would destroy the fragile beauty of the area. The area is not just a place of natural attraction; it is also a home for many people who have chosen to live there because of the balance of living amidst nature.

speech.para: It therefore comes as a shock to learn that Vodafone proposes a major telecommunications tower in the middle of Park Orchards. This is no ordinary tower. It is not one of the ubiquitous poles sporting a collection of antennae and transmitting plates that we see throughout the suburbs of our major cities these days or, indeed, on the tops of buildings in what seems to be every few blocks. What is proposed here is a 40-metre tower, something that would stand the height of a 12-storey office block above the canopy of native eucalypts. It is proposed that this massive structure will have 24 panel antennae and seven rapid transmission disks. The carriers say the structure is necessary to overcome local black spots, but the size and the location suggests that this is either extraordinary overkill on their part or only part of the story. Located as it is on a hill with a clear line of sight to the central business district of Melbourne and to the other major transmitting points in the metropolitan area, mainly Mount Dandenong, many suspect that this is, at least in the future, a major transceiving station in the digital network.

The residents of Park Orchards are concerned about a number of matters, including the amenity of the area, the right of local people to have a say, effectively, over planning proposals, the intrusion of this tower and the health and safety of all in the community, not the least of which are children at nearby schools and preschool centres. What concerns me is that the issue of health and safety appears to fall into a regulatory crack. Honourable members may recall that Labor's original telecommunications legislation had virtually no checks on the placement of towers by carriers. As a result of this government's 1997 changes, low impact facilities—that is, those less than 6.5 metres in height—are free of state and territory planning restrictions but other facilities—those higher than 6.5 metres—are subject to planning laws.

Despite the intent of this legislation, it appears there are still some deficiencies, and I wish to illustrate by reference to the state of Victoria. In Victoria, section 4(c) of the Planning and Environment Act 1987 has the objective of securing a pleasant, efficient and safe working, living and recreational environment for all Victorians. Moreover, the statutory planning provisions provide that the local council must consider not only community needs in the location of telecommunications facilities but the development of the telecommunications network consistent with the economic, environmental and social objectives set out in section 4—in other words, the securing of a safe, working, living and recreational environment for all Victorians. That is what is required by the legislation. Despite this, residents' concerns about the effects of telecommunications towers on them can be, I believe, effectively ignored.

The Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal, whilst accepting the expert evidence that there is not yet—to quote from a decision in the case of Connell Wagner Pty Ltd v. City of Port Phillip, as reported in the 1998 Civil and Administrative Tribunal Reports at page 606—a scientifically sound basis for setting a threshold level for biological effects, has nonetheless said that the Australian standard of 200 microwatts per centimetre squared of electromagnetic radiation exposure is to be applied.

A number of things can be said about this. First, guidelines adopted on precautionary scientific advice by the Sutherland Council in New South Wales, and followed by many other councils, limit the exposure to 0.2 microwatts per centimetre squared—that is, 1,000 times less than the currently permitted level. Moreover, the telecommunications companies have been able to cope with this guideline in the municipalities where it has been applied. In the case of the Park Orchards tower, I am advised that it would mean possibly up to a one-kilometre buffer zone around the proposed facility. I am also aware of the draft industry code which was adopted by the Australian Communications Industry Forum in September 2000 and within which, where it has been applied, telecommunications carriers have apparently been able to work.

While it is arguable that the Victorian Civil and Administrative Tribunal has misdirected itself as a matter of law—for example, their assertion that what is safe can simply be regarded, in the absence of consistent evidence, as an indication of the 200 microwatts limit—a number of other options are currently available. Firstly, the Manningham Council should adopt the Sutherland Council guidelines and apply them to this proposal. I also note in this regard that proposals have been made to Vodafone and other carriers for them to use existing facilities in the area, such as major transmission pylons that are located nearby. Secondly, the Victorian government should amend the Planning and Environment Act to ensure that a responsible planning authority can properly take into account health and safety concerns. Before the last Victorian state election, the Bracks government campaigned on giving local people and local government more say over planning issues. This is an opportunity to fulfil that promise by making amendments, if required, to the Planning and Environment Act in Victoria to clarify the situation.

Thirdly, I urge the Commonwealth to closely monitor this situation. I am aware that a Senate committee is currently examining related issues. I urge the government to consider its report carefully when it is finalised and, if necessary, to consider amending the Commonwealth legislation. This is particularly relevant where, once a permit to build a tower is issued, any number of additional antennae, microwave dishes and the like can be added without further planning approval as long as they do not exceed an additional height of 6.5 metres. What planning approval grants in the first place is the tower, the structure itself. What residents in particular are concerned about are the devices attached to the tower. But, once the tower has been given approval by the local government authority, any number of devices can be added to the tower without any further approval having to be sought.

I also urge some closer consideration of the current proposal to effectively double the standard of 200 microwatts to 449 microwatts per centimetre squared. There does not seem to be a case to increase this. If one accepts the evidence of, for example, Dr Garry Smith—who was responsible for and has carried out the implementation of the Sutherland Council guidelines—it is demonstrated that carriers can operate at a level much lower than even the standard of 200 microwatts that is utilised at the present time. There is no place to increase it; in fact, there may well be a case to decrease the standard. In conclusion, the telecommunications network is important to the country but so too are the health and safety of Australian residents. I regret that Vodafone in this instance have refused my offer for them to meet with residents. I will continue to urge the case on behalf of the residents of Park Orchards.

talk.start.para: —On Thursday, 15 March we marked Public Education Day in this country. It was organised by concerned parents, by P&C associations, by Teachers Federation representatives, by teachers and by people in the community concerned about the future of public education in this country. I had the opportunity on that day to visit quite a number of schools in my electorate. Starting at 8.30 in the morning, I visited Helensburgh Public School, Otford Public School, Stanwell Park Public School, Scarborough Public School, Coledale Public School, Austinmer Public School, Thirroul Public School, Bulli Public School, Waniora Public School, and finally ended up at Bulli High School. I thought it might end there but, no, it did not: there was a demonstration outside my electorate office of concerned residents of my electorate, protesting against what they saw as the Howard government's approach to education funding, particularly the education funding bill that went through the parliament last year, and seeking redress for a range of funding issues associated with that.

speech.para: Last week, I also had the opportunity to attend a public forum that had been organised by the Woonona Public Education Lobby Group. It was held at the Woonona High School auditorium and I and the local state member for Keira, David Campbell, addressed a crowd of people, numbering in the hundreds, representing P&C associations, concerned parents, teachers and so on. The issues that were canvassed there went to things like the present Commonwealth funding arrangements; plans to lift the percentage of GDP funding for education in comparison to other OECD countries; state and Commonwealth responsibilities for funding education; teacher recruitment and how to address looming teacher shortages; growing societal and family dysfunction and its impact on education; what future plans exist for both TAFE and university education; OH&S requirements in terms of older schools. and the need to replace buildings; and, of course, some of the concerns about the state government's back to school allowance in New South Wales.

I have to say that, after such a round of discussions, and following my visits to a number of other schools within my electorate over a long period time, it has become quite clear that there are many issues of concern to Australians about where public education funding is going. We all recall that last year, as part of this government's approach to dealing with these matters, we saw private schools, particularly those in category 1, receive an extra $700 million, but we saw no matching increase to public schools, which educate something like 70 per cent of Australia's children. Even worse than that, we saw something like $56 million go to just 61 wealthy private schools such as King's and Geelong Grammar. The Australian public expect to see reasonable funding for their children in Australia's school system.

From discussions I have had with people in the public education area, it is evident that they want to see that balance swing back: they want to see the government at the national level address some of the funding inadequacies that they perceive—and rightly perceive—to exist. People were suggesting that that balance should tip back to 70 per cent of funding going in favour of public schools. At the other extreme, however, I found that there was an acceptance that, yes, there are low-fee-paying non-government schools in this country that need support and that the majority of that support would come from the Commonwealth government. People recognised, for example, that the Catholic school system needed support. But they were almost as one in their universal condemnation of this government's preparedness to provide additional funds to those schools that basically did not need it. They were concerned about the money going to the likes of the King's School for additional rifle ranges or cricket pitches and so on, when some schools do not even have a school hall for assemblies. They were concerned that some schools do not even have covered walkways to get kids from one end of the school to the other.

In fact, there was a range of issues that were raised with me and I will go through those very quickly. They were as follows: a lack of school hall facilities; old classrooms that were not up to standard and required replacement; airconditioning requirements; P&Cs being forced to pick up the slack on basic items such as photocopying; substandard toilet blocks; substandard office administration space; poorly drained playing fields at some of those schools that were fortunate to have them; problems associated with the provision of sick bays in schools; security for schools' computers—in my electorate, unfortunately, and, I am sure, around Australia, more and more we are seeing people breaking into schools to knock off the computers, to sell them in many cases, I suppose, to facilitate the health problem that many of these people have; incessant changes to the curriculum in many schools; and schools having a budget of only about $70,000 a year to run the entire school when it costs about $300 a day to get a relief teacher to come in when in-service training is required. And, of course, a most pressing and urgent issue which was raised with me was that of school counsellors.

There is a need for funding to be reviewed in this respect. That is why I was so pleased to read today that Premier Carr announced yesterday his intention to put $430 million into the school system for public schools for the replacement of demountable buildings; the construction of buildings, staff rooms and halls; and the installation of heaters and air conditioners in many schools. From what I have seen, that will certainly be welcome. I think what people also have to recognise is that there are state and Commonwealth responsibilities. But I think that, equally, we can be a little lateral in our thinking. For example, I have suggested to people that perhaps the health budget at the national level could be revisited to provide funding for school counsellors, because the problems, identified in the schools, of kids with all sorts of problems stemming from the home environment or whatever it might be are health issues and need to be addressed accordingly. The fact that school counsellors go into schools perhaps only once a week, if they are lucky, to address some of those problems means that those societal problems will stay with those kids throughout life and indeed many of those kids will become the criminals of the future. If we could have counsellors in there, funded perhaps at the national level by the health budget, to give assistance to those teachers in thinking outside the envelope a little, maybe we could stop some of those kids from going on to a life of crime.

It is equally important to outline that, as far as Labor is concerned, we are making education the No. 1 priority of an incoming Beazley Labor government. We have already announced quite a number of policies in this respect and I will outline those very quickly: we propose to introduce education priority zones in disadvantaged areas, abolish the enrolment benchmark adjustment scheme, attract high achievers to teaching through generous scholarships, retrain existing teachers to ensure they have expertise in their subjects, raise literacy and numeracy standards, establish a learning gateway to improve the use of the Internet in classrooms, provide students with after-hours online assistance from teachers, improve and modernise vocational education, ensure that university is more affordable, and of course we will establish the University of Australia online. They are just some of the things that we in the Labor Party have already outlined we would be proposing to do as part of our knowledge nation approach to education and improving standards in this country. What I want to clearly indicate is my commitment to ensuring that education in this country is a right. Labor intends to fund education on the basis of need, and clearly that need is very much alive and well in the public education sector.

You see the dedication of the teaching fraternity in the schools in my electorate and generally in Australia. You see the commitment and the dedication of P&C associations in the public sector and also, I might say, in the private or non-government sector at some of the smaller Catholic schools' P&F associations. You can see them working through raffles, fetes, lamington drives and other fundraising activities to try to find funds to assist in ensuring that the learning environment for Australia's future generations is going to be reasonable. Governments need to address these issues. We must do it at the federal level. The state government—and Premier Carr in New South Wales has started the process—is on the way to doing something about it. Public education is a right; education is a right, and we must address some of those issues to ensure that people get an education that puts them on the path to their future. We now know statistically that people change jobs four times, I think it is, in their working life. We have to ensure that reskilling, retraining and employment generating opportunities through education are created at each one of those steps. It fundamentally starts in primary education; it is extended in secondary education. Public education plays a real role in that way and that support must be forthcoming from Commonwealth governments. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to take the opportunity this afternoon to make some remarks in this chamber about the flurry of activity we have seen in the last 10 days or so concerning greenhouse policy. You might have seen the odd article in our daily press. There was another one this morning purporting to quote the Minister for Foreign Affairs on the subject of the Bush administration's clarification of its policy on this subject. As far as debate here goes, it is worth elucidating some of the reasons as to why this is suddenly being reported.

speech.para: What happened originally was that, on 6 March this year, four United States senators—Senators Hagel, Craig, Helms and Roberts—wrote to President Bush. If I may, I will quote from their letter.

quote.para: Dear Mr President:
We write to seek clarification of your Administration's policy on climate change.

We are aware that your Administration has recently begun a formal interagency review of climate change policies. Yet on Tuesday February 27, Environmental Protection Agency Administrator Christine Todd Whitman testified on this subject before the Senate ...

speech.para: It goes on to say:

quote.para: Administrator Whitman stated at this hearing that the Administration would seek to make the Kyoto Protocol workable. She went on to advocate the regulation of carbon dioxide under the Clean Air Act. She called for, “putting [carbon dioxide] into the process and recognizing that we have to deal with it, which would be to put on a cap of some sort, a target anyway.”

The United States Senate is on record regarding the Kyoto Protocol. In July 1997, the Senate voted 95-0 for S. Res. 98, a resolution that called on the President not to sign any climate change treaty that would—

speech.para: among other things—

quote.para: cause serious harm to the U.S. economy ...

speech.para: The senators went on to say:

quote.para: We look forward to working with you and your Administration on the development of a comprehensive national energy strategy ... However, we need to have a clear understanding of your Administration's position on climate change, in particular the Kyoto Protocol, and the regulation of carbon dioxide ...

speech.para: This was quite a letter, as the tone of it would suggest. Coming from some senior members of the Senate, it clearly generated a rapid response from President Bush, who wrote back on 13 March to Senator Hegel saying:

quote.para: Dear Senator Hagel:
Thank you for your letter of March 6, asking for the Administration's views on global climate change, in particular the Kyoto protocol ...

speech.para: He went on to say:

quote.para: As you also know, I support a comprehensive and balanced national energy policy that takes into account the importance of improving air quality ...

speech.para: He also said:

quote.para: As you know, I oppose the Kyoto Protocol because it exempts 80 percent of the world, including major population centres such as India and China, from compliance, and would cause serious harm to the U.S. economy. The Senate's vote, 95-0, vote shows that there is a clear consensus that the Kyoto Protocol is an unfair and ineffective means of addressing global climate change concerns.

speech.para: That is again quite a reply from the President. It makes it very clear—as his national security adviser, Ms Condoleeza Rice, is reportedly quoted in an article of the Financial Review telling European Union ambassadors at a meeting in Washington last week—that Mr Bush's stance meant that the Kyoto process was dead.

In the light of that and in the light of comments by some of our ministers clearly endorsing the approach of the United States administration to this treaty and to the issue of climate change, we have to consider what we are going to do about it here in Australia henceforth. It is quite clear that the view is that if there is no participation of developing countries in this proposed scheme then there can be no scheme for industrialised countries such as Australia and certainly the United States. Clearly, if the United States is not going to go along with a system or a plan of caps on the emissions of carbon dioxide, it is sheer fantasy to believe that the People's Republic of China would ever agree to emission caps; and thereafter you would see other large emitters of carbon dioxide or the large economies in the developing world—India, Indonesia and Brazil—doing the same thing. It is quite clear they are never going to agree to it. So Kyoto, which was originally conceived, I think, as the first step in a radical plan to decarbonise industrialised society, is going to fail.

There is, nonetheless, a lot of money being spent on research into this, not simply in the International Panel on Climate Change, which is the body of scientific advisers established under the original climate change framework convention—these advisers are the most ferocious proponents of the Kyoto protocol—but also outside that. In a sense, there are some interesting developments bringing to light some contrary scientific theories regarding the greenhouse effect, not so much about whether there is a greenhouse effect—of course there is; if there were not the earth would freeze every night—but about how the planet may be adapting to an increasing amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere. There is an interesting article in the latest edition, volume 82, of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society by three authors, two from NASA's Goddard Institute, Arthur Hou and Ming Da Chou, together with Professor Richard Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The scientists have been studying cloud cover over the Pacific Ocean and they have discovered that, as the sea surface temperature increases, the clouds above those areas where the sea surface temperature is particularly high have been reacting in such a way as to permit the release of infra-red energy to outer space, if you like, providing a heat vent in the atmosphere which acts to stabilise the temperature in that particular region. If this natural feedback stabiliser is a genuine phenomenon, as these very senior climate scientists have observed, then the important thing about it is that it has not been included in any of the computer models used by the scientists who have been making predictions of large climate change. These new developments, unless incorporated in the models, cast some doubt about how up to date those models are.

Another piece of science that caught my eye was published in the October 2000 edition of the magazine Nature. It deals with the sequestration of carbon in the ocean interior. It talks about the presence of carbon dioxide in ice cores taken in the Antarctic and it focuses on the possible action, as I think you would describe it, of the ocean as a carbon sink and how, over the great trends in temperature change during the past few centuries, it may be that the ocean itself adapts at certain times to absorb more carbon when there is more carbon in the atmosphere. Again, for those interested in the topic and where it is going scientifically, this is well worth reading.

The point now is this: what are we to do in Australia about this? A large amount of money was allocated a couple of budgets ago to the Australian Greenhouse Office for research into this issue of climate change and what it might mean for Australia. I note, like everyone else in this House, that there has been an astonishing amount of advertising material in the newspapers and lately on the television by the Australian Greenhouse Office pointing to measures that individual citizens can take—for example, among other things, taking shorter showers. To believe that taking shorter showers is somehow going to contribute to a mitigation of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere is, to put it politely, drawing a very long bow. I would prefer to see some of this money spent not so much on advertising in our media but on agricultural science and on developing or forecasting the methods which we will require to adapt to climate change if it comes. If climate change does not happen as rapidly as the IPCC predicts, then the money will not be said to have been wasted. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to join with my colleague the member for Cunningham in speaking about public education. On 15 March the first ever National Public Education Day was held. Public Education Day was celebrated around the country in cities and in rural and regional areas. It was celebrated in the 39 government primary and eight government high schools in my electorate of Charlton. The first ever Public Education Day celebrated the achievements of public education and sought to defend public education from the attacks by this government over the past five years. Teachers, parents and students all joined in that Thursday to celebrate and protect public education. Our local ABC radio conducted its broadcast all day from Newcastle High School. The journalists spoke with everybody involved in that public school: the principal, the students, the parents, the teachers, the support workers, the counsellors, and all the friends of public education.

speech.para: Amongst other events, I attended an afternoon tea at Warners Bay High School in my electorate, organised by the P&C, the students and the principal, Ms Kerri Leigh-Gordon. I took the opportunity that afternoon to speak with the school leaders, Darwin Natano, Liam Holmes, Bianca Murphy and Adee Antebey. I was impressed and inspired, but not surprised, with their intelligence, nous and commonsense. They were articulate and able to debate various issues. We spoke about youth issues and feminism, about work and family responsibilities and about politics. It was great to see our young Australians becoming involved in the political debate in our public schools.

There are 7,000 public schools in Australia, and two million parents of students in public schools, but nationally we have reached the disgraceful point where this federal government spends only 32 per cent of its schools expenditure on the 70 per cent of Australia's children who benefit from public education. To quote Denis Fitzgerald, the Federal President of the Australian Education Union, we have the best education system in the world, and we aim to keep it that way. I would like to reiterate to Denis that he and his members can include me in that `we' and all of my colleagues in the Australian Labor Party.

Let me look now at the history of this government with its ideological undermining of our public education system. The government's enrolment benchmark adjustment ripped away $60 million from public schools. In the schools funding legislation last year, the minister handed $60 million which was lost from 7,000 public schools to 60 category 1 private schools. I will read out just 12 of those schools which will receive millions of dollars over the next four years: Trinity Grammar in New South Wales, $3.1 million; Newington in New South Wales, an extra $1.8 million; the King's School in Parramatta, an extra $1.5 million; Wesley College in Victoria, $3.9 million; Caulfield Grammar in Victoria, $3.6 million; Haileybury in Victoria, $2.9 million; Ivanhoe Grammar in Victoria, $2.4 million; Geelong College in Victoria, $2.3 million; Geelong Grammar in Victoria, $1.7 million; Mentone Grammar in Victoria, $1.6 million; Scotch College in Victoria, an extra $1 million; and St Peters Collegiate in South Australia, an extra $1.5 million.

During previous debates we have heard about the types of facilities that this government money will assist in funding. For example, the King's School in Parramatta, which charges fees of up to $11,500 a year for day students, advertises the following facilities: 15 cricket fields, five basketball courts, 12 tennis courts, a 50-metre swimming pool, a gym, two climbing walls, an indoor rifle range, 13 rugby fields, three soccer fields, a cross-country course and a boat shed.

Last August the Prime Minister said that these new funding arrangements were designed to `provide more resources in a more accurate way to those communities in the independent sector that are more deserving of assistance'. That is just wrong. Just today in an article in the Australian, the principal of Geelong Grammar School was quoted as saying:

quote.para: ... to be able to afford Geelong Grammar fees puts you in a certain category ... the reality of it is that a number of our students here come from highly privileged backgrounds.

speech.para: The article goes on to say that the Geelong Grammar council has been worried about the school's image of inaccessibility and was looking to change its profile in the community as the exclusive domain of the rich; but, as Ebru Yaman reports, with fees for year 12 more than $15,000 a year for day students and about $25,000 for boarders, the school inevitably remains out of the reach of most families. In stark contrast to these wealthy schools, visitors to our public schools on Public Education Day, while being delighted and inspired by the quality of education provided by public schools, would have been angered by the resource levels and maintenance arrears in some schools. Visitors would have seen teachers working in their own time to help students in need and to teach drama, dance and sport.They would have seen parent volunteers, community volunteers, Aboriginal volunteers and many more united in their determination to provide the best possible outcomes for the children in their local schools.

One of those volunteers is Gordon Triplett. Gordon helps students at Booragul primary school with writing and reading in particular but assists wherever he can. Last year Gordon received a Commonwealth Recognition Award for Older Australians in appreciation of his contribution to the Booragul school community.

I am proud to say that I was educated in the public system. I attended Kurri Kurri Primary School and Kurri Kurri High School. I was able to attend Canberra University without having to pay fees. Both my parents were teachers and deputy principals in public high schools. I can remember as a young child attending anti-Vietnam war rallies carrying banners and wearing T-shirts which read `It will be a great day when public education has all the funding it needs and the Air Force has to hold a cake stall to buy a bomber'. Unfortunately, our communities are still pleading for that level of funding, though fortunately not against a backdrop of war. I would like to read into Hansard two of the letters that I have received following Public Education Day. The first one is from Booragul Public School:

quote.para: Dear Kelly,
The staff of Booragul Public School congratulate you for being one of the few members of the Federal Parliament who choose to send their own children to public schools.
We also thank you for your personal stand in party forums and the Parliament which defend public education and its funding.

The undersigned would like to take the opportunity to tell you to warn the coalition through Mr Howard & Dr Kemp and your own party through Messrs Beazley & Lee that we expect future policy to go against current trends. All politicians should be warned that we expect public moneys to fund public schools. Public schools provide an inclusive education.

speech.para: The letter goes on:

quote.para: We had our largest community turnout in daylight hours in many years yesterday when we held our school's Public Education Day assembly with only a few days' notice of the event. We would ask you to remind your parliamentary peers of this level of support for public schooling.

speech.para: It is signed by Iain Macpherson of the New South Wales Teachers Federation. Iain is a gallant and tireless advocate for public education in our area. The other letter is from Edgeworth Heights Public School:

quote.para: Public education is the cornerstone of our democracy and one of the reasons that Australians live in the most peaceful nation on Earth.

Students from public schools are among our nation's greatest achievers. Students in public schools have the opportunity to meet and relate to others from many different backgrounds and they benefit from the knowledge and skills of dedicated teachers who are proud to be making a difference.
Today in public schools and TAFE colleges across Australia we are celebrating public education—its achievements and its progress.
The Edgeworth Heights School community support public education and calls on you to ensure that public education is pre-eminent in the decision-making of government.”

speech.para: I want to take a brief moment to respond to those schools and all the people in my community who, along with me, believe in, support and will unite to protect good quality public education for all Australians. The Labor opposition will campaign on the issue of fair funding for government and non-government schools until the next election. The Hon. Kim Beazley, Leader of the Opposition, has introduced a private member's bill which proposes to change the inequitable aspects of the government's funding arrangements for schools. The Australian Labor Party has always staunchly defended public education. It remains a key tenet of a civilised society and government must ensure that adequate public funding is provided for an inclusive education for our children.

I congratulate all involved in making Public Education Day a huge success: the Australian Council of State School Organisations, the Australian Education Union, local parent organisations and principals organisations, and, of course, our local school communities—teachers, students, other staff and school friends. Only the minister diminished the day by using it as a platform to attack Labor and the AEU. In conclusion, I would like to quote the President of the Australian Council of State School Organisations, Rodney Molesworth, speaking on Public Education Day, a celebration of achievement:

quote.para: Public Education Day will highlight the vibrant, progressive, and inclusive cultures of public schools, and their outstanding outcomes across the whole range of the aims of schooling. It will also draw attention to the policies of political parties and the threat that some of these pose to the institution underpinning this nation's future peace and prosperity.

speech.para: I would like to say to all those who support public education: I support public education, the Australian Labor Party supports public education and we will continue to do so. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Last month two fine Australians died. Both lived their lives as a shining example of courage, integrity and singular commitment to personal goals and values that raised them high in the great vortex of human endeavour. One is known and loved for his spectacular talent and ability in his chosen field of sport and the other, lesser known perhaps, has been recognised for her loyalty and her courage against evil. Both, however, were known for their standards, their principles and their family values and for the way they quietly lived god-fearing lives as true blue citizens of Australia.

speech.para: Both these exceptional Australians lived extraordinary lives, and both will continue to command their own place within our national psyche for their own very special contributions that they have made in making Australia a little finer for the rest of us and for our children. The first, of course, is Sir Donald Bradman, who died on 25 February this year. As others have laurelled his life far better than I, it is enough for me to add that, in addition to his superiority as the world's greatest batsman, he also lived an exemplary life of principle, of love for his wife and family and of respect for his fellow human beings.

The other Australian who lived an extraordinary life died only one day before Sir Donald. Her name was Barbara Mackay, a woman whose life reminded us that evil will always prosper when good people do nothing. Of course you will remember that Barbara Mackay was the wife of murdered anti-drug campaigner Donald Mackay, and her death should be a clarion, shrilly reminding each and every one of us that we ignore these warnings about violence at our own peril and at the peril of our children.

Today I would like to record my personal tribute to the courageous Barbara Mackay for her principled stand against illicit drugs and official corruption and also for her achievements in the area of drug rehabilitation. I take no pride in stating that Barbara Mackay did this important work against a backdrop of attempts to vilify her as a widow and physical threats to herself and the surviving members of her family, following her husband's assassination in 1977. Donald Mackay was murdered because of the effectiveness of his anti-drug campaign in the heartland of illicit drug production and distribution in the Griffith district of New South Wales during the 1970s.

In one of life's little ironies, Barbara Mackay died only a few weeks after the assassin hired to kill her husband was released from prison. James Frederick Bazley, now aged 75, walked free despite a life sentence for the murder of the drug couriers Isobel and Douglas Wilson and for the conspiracy to murder Donald Mackay. It was alleged that ethnically based organised crime bosses paid Bazley $10,000 to execute Mr Mackay in a hotel car park in Griffith on the evening of 15 July 1977 and to dispose of his body. The perpetrators who were responsible for ordering and paying for his killing have never been brought to justice. We can only hope that, with the reflection that comes in later life, someone's conscience will speak to them loud enough for them to come forward and confess the truth. The full truth was never revealed to the public, despite quite a lot being known about organised crime in Griffith at that time—a good deal of which was revealed in the 1979 Woodward Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking report, which even named identities.

It was the circumstances of Mr Mackay's murder that stopped the nation at the time. It was not the result of a failure in human relationships or a criminal dispute; it was a murder that involved official corruption and, as such, it remains a blot on the official life of Australia. Had justice prevailed in the 1970s, we may have learned lessons that could have helped in the present day combat against ethnically based organised drug crime in Australia. Perhaps John Newman would still be alive and still be the state member for a very different Cabramatta from that which exists today.

Donald Mackay was killed because his antidrug activities were endangering the profits flowing from illicit drug production and distribution by well connected people in the Griffith area. Those profits directly and indirectly enriched many people whose hands today are stained with the blood of Donald Mackay. Mr Mackay also campaigned against corruption of people in high places, people with power and positions of influence and all those who, by either their omission or their commission, cleared the way for organised crime to succeed.

Barbara Mackay died before she could publish her book entitled Before I Forget. It was due to be released on the 20th anniversary of Donald Mackay's death in 1997 but was forced to be withdrawn on legal advice. This is another irony as it seems that, while the classification laws legalise the publication of sleaze, the defamation laws in our country outlaw the publication of truth. As Barbara Mackay said, `My husband was effectively silenced, and now it is my turn.' In an interview shown on the ABC's 7.30 Report on 3 December 1991, Barbara Mackay said:

quote.para: I think one of the frustrating things is that constantly people are saying to you: `We're looking after it', you know, `we've got it in hand'. The Premier, right at the beginning, said: `We shall leave no stone unturned', and you realise it's just garbage, you know, they've got no commitment to change.

speech.para: Both Donald Mackay and his wife, Barbara, have passed from this world now, and the least we can do is to put on the record our regret that official Australia let them down and that the elected representatives of the people failed to heed the warning written all over Donald Mackay's murder.

Our inaction has won us a terrible double-barrelled legacy. Firstly, there are the thousands of young people caught in the net of suicide or other mental illness induced in full or in part by marijuana, the so-called soft, harmless or recreational drug. It was this drug that the Griffith mafia did so much to promote and entrench in Australia's youth culture, and this is more blood on their hands. For many, marijuana has been the door to heroin addiction and worse. Secondly, today there are approximately 70,000 heroin and methadone addicts who are the disabled product of organised crime and the tolerant official policy attitude to the use of illicit drugs that the Mackays strove so courageously to expose and that still continues and remains the official policy.

Today, we still fail to heed the warnings of other areas of violence against the minds of our young people. I refer to the horror that passes as entertainment today. A few weeks ago the rap performer known as Eminem won three prestigious Grammys for his music that had sold eight million recordings. In the lyrics, he talks of killing his wife and his mother. According to the widely read entertainment paper the Rolling Stone, the lyrics were a masterpiece. These lyrics are certainly not a masterpiece to wives and mothers. Despite the protestations of the music industry, the eight million buyers of this demonic material are immature children and youth, for whom they are designed and to whom they are marketed and targeted. The Rolling Stone article I referred to earlier and the other industry comments are the same sort of vested interest protection that was used to cover up the corruption that the Mackays tried to expose in the area of illicit drugs.

The leader of another pop group, Marilyn Manson, who performed to tens of thousands of Australian youth, is Brian Warner, an ordained minister of the Church of Satan in the United States. Some of his raps include, `Kill God, kill your parents and kill yourself.' I am informed that he once tossed a six-week-old puppy into the audience and encouraged the kids to rip it to pieces and to smear the blood on one another, which they did. Regretfully, his kind of `entertainment' has been promoted in Australia by Triple J. This is the same sort of lack of judgment by people in official and responsible positions and the same sort of failure to act that undermined the Mackay murder investigation.

There are more important consequences than entertainment industry profits. Two young followers of Marilyn Manson known as the Trench Coat Mafia, screaming out `Marilyn Manson rules', carried out the massacre of 13 classmates at Colombine High School in 1999. Their targets were mostly Christian students who had spoken out against Manson's music of hate.

A further encouragement of desensitisation to violence and killing was recently released in the film Hannibal. This feature film contains a graphic sequence in which one character eats a man's brain. The Office of Film and Literature Classification did not have the brains to appropriately classify Hannibal, and the Attorney-General had to intervene and get it reclassified. Can any of us really imagine someone of the stature of Don Bradman going to see rubbish like this? Why in the world do we allow our children? One of the daily Sydney newspapers reported two 14-year-old children who had been allowed in to see Hannibal. One has to ask whether or not the movie operators were ever prosecuted for breaching the classification regulations.

There is too much violence in the media and in the live entertainment industry at any hour of the day or night. To varying degrees, it is desensitising our children and adults alike. It is not only the classifiers who are failing to protect our children from harm; there is not enough law enforcement of videos and this sort of entertainment at the state level. Last year, a Sydney teenager who murdered a 15-year-old boy at Katoomba was desensitised to killing him by viewing snuff movies. These videos showed real-life scenes of killing, cruelty and torture. He had been introduced to snuff movies by his satanist drug dealer. He said that he felt queasy the first time he was shown the movies but that over time he came to feel a rush or a thrill. It seems that there is no specific offence for the possession of snuff movies, and I have been unable to identify any convictions in regard to them. In fact, the low number of convictions for breaches of any of the classification laws is evidence of its low law enforcement priority, despite the ever-increasing evidence of harm.

Official attitudes are changing in the United States, even under the Clinton administration, where they are beginning to treat TV violence as a public health issue. There are reports that the US Surgeon General is about to release a report that concludes that the old debate about the effects of exposure to TV violence is over. Graphically violent entertainment hurts children. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to talk in the grievance debate today about banks—and what a thing to grieve over! We have witnessed increasingly arrogant behaviour from the banks in this country over recent times. We have seen closures of banks occur with regularity. We have seen fee increases as almost the norm and probably never with any acceptable excuse or explanation to the customer base they are affecting. Within my electorate in recent times, three branches have closed or are due to close. The Westpac branch at Curtin closed in April last year. That was followed by the Commonwealth branch at Wanniassa in January 2001 and the National Australia branch at Phillip will be closing in May. I will briefly outline what happened in each of these cases.

speech.para: On 4 April last year I received a letter from Westpac's regional manager, ACT and southeast New South Wales region, telling me that they were not going to close a branch—and this is what I found very cute—that they were going to amalgamate the Curtin and Woden branches. I call that a closure but they choose to call it an amalgamation. The letter came to me dated 4 April and the closure, or amalgamation, occurred on 28 April, just over three weeks later. In the letter they said, amongst other things:

quote.para: I can assure you that this decision to amalgamate the Curtin and Woden branches was only taken after detailed analysis of such key business issues as:
Changes in retail shopping patterns in the area.
The way in which Curtin branch customers carry out their banking.
The overall level of customer usage of the Curtin branch.
I am sure you would recognise that the information considered in this analysis is commercial-in-confidence.

speech.para: In other words, it is all a top-secret to them as to how they came to the decision to close the Curtin branch and move their business into Woden. I disregard the word amalgamation, I think it is very cheeky. That is what happened in relation to the Curtin branch of Westpac. I contacted the business sector surrounding that branch in the retail area of Curtin and found that a number of them were going to close their business with Westpac and move to the Commonwealth, a branch of which still existed at the Curtin shops at the time, and I believe it still does.

The next closure was the Commonwealth branch at Wanniassa. I received a letter from their regional manager, sales and service, dated 1 December 2000, to tell me that on 12 January 2001, the Commonwealth's Wanniassa branch would cease operations. They said:

quote.para: The decision to close this branch was taken only after a thorough investigation of many factors, including both current and future business trends, customer usage and the alternative services.

speech.para: One of the alternative services they told their customers to go to was the Post Office, without realising that the Post Office had also closed, but that is another issue. I took them to task and wrote to them outlining my concerns on behalf of my constituency. They wrote back and said:

quote.para: The decision to close this branch was taken only after a thorough investigation of all factors affecting the Commonwealth Bank's business.

speech.para: I find that a notable comment because it talks about the Commonwealth Bank's business but does not mention its customers. Further down, the letter says:

quote.para: Closure of any branch is contemplated only where business levels have not met our expectations to the extent that a difficult decision had to be made.

speech.para: Then there is the very telling sentence—

quote.para: It is not normal practice to involve local business or community consultation about the decision to close a branch.

speech.para: Thank you very much. No wonder they are only considering factors affecting the Commonwealth Bank's business because they admit to me that they do not do anything in relation to consultation with local business or local community people. They also say:

quote.para: People who still use passbooks for over-the-counter withdraws may be impacted by the branch closure...The pricing of our product range is geared to offer substantial savings to our customers who use card based electronic mechanisms and there is genuine financial gain and convenience for our customers.

speech.para: They also say that they understand that it will unfortunately deprive some of their customers of a convenience. It certainly does. It certainly also indicates to me the absolute manipulation by the banks of the marketplace. In other words, if you want to sell more of one product and less of another, you gear your fees and costs accordingly and you make sure that the one that you want to get rid of is the one that is most difficult for the customer to maintain. And that is exactly what that bank has indicated it does, as I think others do as well, by saying, `Look, if they get rid of their passbooks, we won't need that branch. So we'll do that by making our other services a little bit cheaper for them.' But that is without any regard for the needs of the customers concerned.

The third closure that we are facing now is the National Australia Bank, which tells us that they are going to be closing their Phillip South branch on 23 May. They say that `due to a decline in customer traffic and over-the-counter transactions' they are deciding to close that branch. When I rang the person suggested in that letter and asked for more details—as I was encouraged to do—a funny thing occurred. The bank officer I spoke to said, `Look, whenever I visit that branch on behalf of the bank it is virtually empty—nobody there.' They then went on to say, however, that the four staff who were in that branch would probably be located elsewhere but the bank was going to employ five more people at the levels of II, II and I in three close-by branches to handle the customer overflow from the closure of Phillip. Now, you cannot have it both ways—you cannot have an empty bank and, at the same time, confess that you have to employ people in other branches in the area to handle the overflow of that closure. It is terribly arrogant and, I think, unbelievably contradictory.

I believe the attitude of the banks has got to the point where the community is demanding something be done. My community has made it very clear to me at every opportunity they have that the banks must learn again to respect the various needs of their customers, to value each one of them, regardless of their economic or social situation, and to ensure that they judge their continuing success not only by the margin of their huge profits but also by the service to and consideration of each of their customers. I do not for one moment say that banks should not make a profit—they are happy to—but they cannot do it at the cost to these other customers.

I am very pleased today to see the release of the Labor Party policy for better banking because that policy has the very things that I have been talking about. It has the social charter of community obligations for banks which will be legally binding on those banks. If the banks refuse to negotiate that acceptable social charter, a Labor government will impose a charter through legislation. That charter will be developed in close consultation with the banking industry, consumers, pension allowance recipients, community groups, representatives of rural and regional Australia, and other interest groups. The social charter will be legally enforceable, as any contract is. We do not believe that a social charter has any point at all unless it is absolutely enforceable.

In relation to the three local branch closures that we have seen in recent times in my electorate, it is interesting to see in our policy platform that where a bank proposes closing a branch, Labor will ensure that communities are consulted. So the bank that said that they do not talk to anybody about it and that their surveys are commercial-in-confidence will have to have a new approach to the way they relate to their client base and their community, and I will be very pleased to see that. We also say in our policy that a notice period of six months will be required for each branch closure to allow communities to find alternatives. My community in Tuggeranong, where the Wanniassa branch of the Commonwealth closed, are currently attempting to get up a community bank—and good on them because if these banks will not service that community maybe a community bank will.

The other thing in our platform that I am pleased to see is that banks will be required to consult with communities prior to a bank closure, and so they should. So a three-week notice from the Westpac bank about the closure of the Curtin branch last year will no longer be able to happen. And it means that the Commonwealth, the NAB—and, in fact, the whole lot of them—are going to have to come to grips with the fact that a Labor government, when we are in power, will simply not allow to happen what has been happening in the past—an absolute and total cheap disregard for those community customers out there, who are very important individuals, who see a great value in their communication with their bank and who have a history of supporting those banks in the past. I applaud that policy released today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise in the House today to again bring to the House's attention the importance of the Roads to Recovery program to local councils, particularly local councils in my electorate of New England. There has been quite considerable discussion on the Roads to Recovery program and the fact that it is delivering for our road networks in regional Australia a much needed and long overdue level of service that we have been unable to provide through local government for a long time. In the 11 years that I was involved in local councils as a councillor and then as a mayor one of the dreams I had was to see funds coming to our local council roads to fix that little culvert or that bit of road that had always been boggy in rainy times and to be able to ensure that the children of the people who lived out on properties were able to get to school.

speech.para: Quite often, when we talk about council roads, people in the city seem to take for granted the fact that they always have access to be able to get out and go to school or go to the shops whereas I can assure you, in country areas that has not been the case. When I look at the Roads to Recovery program and what it has delivered direct from the Commonwealth to local councils, I think it is tremendous. In my electorate alone, over the four-year period of the Roads to Recovery program, it will deliver an extra $23 million direct to local councils for their local road network. In fact, as there are two payments due before the end of June this year, that is directly putting about $2.8 million extra into the road network.

Last week I went out with the mayor of one of my local councils, the Guyra Shire Council, together with some of its councillors and engineers, to have a look at the work being done on many of the roads that were pinpointed years ago as desperately needing a gravel resheeting program. To stand there on the side of these roads while the trucks were rolling was incredible because you are physically seeing, for the first time, substantial works being done which will bring direct benefits to the people who live in those areas.

I pay tribute to the Guyra Shire Council, its mayor, Robyn Jackson, and its five councillors; to Geoff Brooks, the general manager, and his engineering staff, led by David Wolfendon; and to works engineer, Andrew Dance. I also take this opportunity to congratulate the staff of Guyra Shire Council, those who drive the trucks and the graders and those who provide the supervision for these works to be done, because they are rolling out a gravel resheeting program at about a kilometre per day. That is quite an achievement when you consider the old standards that people used to use. They are using a combination of their own day labour—which is, as I say, highly trained and very professional—and subcontractors, particularly with the trucks and their dozer work. To see the level of professionalism that one of their new grader drivers who has just started on the graders is bringing to the job is, I think, a credit to the whole staff.

Why I have taken the time to go through this today is that I believe that this has been one of the most significant programs that this government have been able to deliver for our road network, whether it is in the federal seat of New England or indeed the seat of the minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, the member for Maranoa—an enormous electorate. His seat borders my seat and I know that his councils have written to him expressing their appreciation for the extra funding and, as I say, mine have as well.

talk.start.para: —It is not a boondoggle.

—It is not a boondoggle at all. The Labor Party seem to think that country roads are something that nobody should look after and that funds should not be allocated to them. It is important that we recognise that there are people living on roads which often do not get their fair share of taxpayers' money. For example, I know that 4.9 kilometres of resheeting is being done on the Old Armidale Road by Guyra Shire Council in the electorate of New England. I know that people who travel that road to take their stock to market or in turn to receive superphosphate and other inputs to their farm certainly appreciate the fact that that work is being done. Brushy Creek Road is only a small road, but it is vitally important and the council has been able to do a gravel resheeting program in areas where it was very boggy. There has been $2,600 spent on that road. I am joined here by the member for Parkes who also has a keen interest in local council roads.
—Another endangered species!

—That again shows that the Labor Party has no conception of what is happening in the country. The member for Parkes is also aware of the need to get this money paid directly to councils, not for it to be put back through the states. Jackson Road is to have $7,800 spent on it. The Moredum Dams Road is very important not only for the local industry but also for tourism. Under the Roads to Recovery program, $29,000 worth of work is going into that road alone. Junction Road is another one that carries a lot of traffic, $20,000; the Falls Road, $6,800; the Hilton Road, $5,100; and $28,000 worth of work is to go into Ramah Road, an enormous amount. As I look at the map of the shire and the way that the engineer has been able to split up this work—over the years I have travelled all those sections of road—I notice that the work covers the whole of the shire from the eastern side right through to the west and through to the Ben Lomond region.

speech.para: People in my electorate in particular are just so pleased that the Howard-Anderson government has delivered substantial funds to our local council road networks. As we look at some of the larger shires in my electorate and the programs that they have undertaken, we see that Inverell Council has a very large area to look after. Under this program, they receive an extra $826,000 per year for the next four years. Their engineer, Greg Moran, and the mayor, Barry Johnston, have both taken great delight in advising me of council's readiness to get into the work, to get the gravel resheeting programs down and to get some new culverts in a lot of areas where they have been washed away or have been eroded over a period of time. Even in the smaller councils in my electorate, in Manilla for example, Paul McManus and his team have an extra $265,000 a year coming into their road network for the delivery of gravel resheeting programs. They were unable to complete some roads, as the funds they were receiving were insufficient.

I am not suggesting for one moment that we should stop at the end of this program. I believe it should be an ongoing program. I still do not believe that it is enough money to be spent on our local council road networks. What we have to do, though, is to put pressure on the New South Wales Minister for Transport, Carl Scully, and on Mr Bob Carr to get them to spend some of their money on the state road network. I have a road that actually runs right through the Guyra Shire Council, Main Road 135 or the Guyra to Ebor road, that is still unsealed—a major road. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.
